Evaluation_Questions: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?
Comments_Questions: How well was the course organized?
How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
The course goals were clearly presented.
The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
The grading criteria was clearly explained.
The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
I would recommend this instructor to other students.
How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
Did you attend all the discussions?
Comments_List: There is a vast difference between TAs and how they hold their sessions accountable for attendance. Nahuel meticulously recorded tardiness and absences but other TAs did not which left students of the same course being held to different standards.
It certainly has it's way of functioning...

This truly depends on the TA and their structure for the discussion group. Nahuel was brilliant and led an informative and engaging discussion whereas Ashley led a group that actively discussed but with what often felt like no structured purpose. 

In the main lecture, this balance did not exist on any level. Paul presented in full lecture except the first lesson on the first day of fall semester (which was the best class lecture he had).
Would be a better balance if lecturing material was presented in a more digestible way.
Paul got a lot better this semester about making eye contact in case we had a question.

I think it would depend on what the true aim of the course was... The essay assignment this semester did not lend itself to the study of theatre history or the developments within, rather it focused on the dramaturgical analysis of a script of choice. Which then begs the question -- is this a theatre history course or a dramaturgy 101 course?
Not sure I understand the aim of the course as constructed.

Again, this depends on the TA leading the session. Nahuel constantly referenced the weekly reading as well as the Fuchs essay, preparing us from day 1 to think through the essay as we talked about the readings. On the other hand, Ashley rarely if ever mentioned / referenced the readings.
Was generally manageable.

I didn't do any of it. Because there was way too much.
Its also unclear if the purpose of discussion was to discuss the plays or the lectures.
There were no supplementary materials for this semester.

Specifically the video lectures at the top where I could adjust the pace and pause to take notes. Also, if in-class lectures resembled more closely how the video seemed to be - where the material being verbalized matched the slide - that would help.

I think the video lectures are a good idea and were a great resource for people who were ESL or just had learning styles that make it difficult for them to absorb information audibly. The video lectures give people the opportunity to pause and take more useful notes. 

I think going forward the way in which the PowerPoint lectures are used could be reexamined. Right now they are clearly being used as a visual aide meant to accompany the lecture, where pictures or images offer context for what is being said by the speaker but offer very little informational value on their own. The PPs are the primary resource students use for studying for the exams and, in my experience, finding the pertinent information in the slideshows can be difficult because they weren't designed to be independently informative but to be an auxiliary lecture took. I would like to see the use of these PowerPoint to be re-examined because I think with the speed of the lectures many people dont have the opportunity to take very detailed notes and therefore rely on these slideshows for review.
I did not have time to look at the supplementary materials.

We touched on technological changes throughout history a few times but entirely ignored it after the 18th century. The focus of the course seemed very much to be more along the lines of the history of dramaturgy rather than truly embracing all disciplines of theatre through all aspects of the course.

Yes and could have learned more if this course wasn't seemingly set up for struggle against the rest of YSD - This isn't a Paul problem but a culture of exhaustion problem. Additionally, YSD focus is on production work not academics.

This is the part of the course where I felt like I had a much better understanding from previous studies. It felt very surface level, especially considering this is probably the more relevant part of the course.

If this course weren't required, you wouldn't get anyone to voluntarily sign up for it. The workload is tough and the focus of the lectures focuses too much on the dramaturg's point of interest rather than all departments.
One semester of it, yes.
Yes
Knowing the history and diversity of our theatrical traditions is essential and I'm deeply discouraged by the lack of historical curiosity by many of peers.
For a survey of theater history I think it was good.
No. Very talky, and too much work for what its worth.
Not if there, not literally studying theater history or dramaturg.
I don't actually know what the course goals were... and spring semester did not involve a syllabus or discussion of one at all.
Who knows...
Paul's knowledge was never up for debate. He is clearly very knowledgeable and passionate.
Instructor's and TA's were knowledgeable, improvements could be made on gifting that knowledge.
Paul is a genius.

Paul is a world class theater historian and I believe he is working very hard to bring as many cultures and peoples in to the conversation as possible. It's a difficult task being the shortage of lecture time he has to teach 4000 years of history over the myriad of cultures, which results in unfortunate things being omitted or breezed over like covering 1000 years of Japanese theatre in one day, but I appreciate that to give more time to one subject means to take away from another and I cant imagine, going through the course, what i would eliminate from the syllabus.
Clearly very knowledgeable.

Again, he is very knowledgeable and passionate about the course materials. However, the lecture moves a mile a minute and the powerpoint offers up entirely different information making it near impossible to take effective notes during lecture. Depending on which TA you get will determine whether you are able to take effective notes during session to make up for the lecture. Paul posts the power points on canvas but they are extremely difficult to follow without the lectures because of how he puts in multiple slides showing the same information... He also refuses to give out his lectures unless the students are english as a second language / foreign students. If Paul is going to continue his format and lecture style, I honestly think he should write a textbook for the course so that all students can have a chance to feel adequately prepared for exams, lectures, and discussion.
In some ways.
Some of the lecture slides had too much text and it was impossible to read them and absorb the info while Paul was talking.
Lectures were well organized but it was easy to get lost and then not be able to pay attention or catch up.
There was rarely time for any dialogue with Paul and seemed to be a late add to the end of the second semester.
Paul was on the money about hearing diverse perspectives.
No real time for that in lectures, and pretty rails on in sections
See above.

Again, I appreciate the scarcity of time and trying to cover as much ground as possible in the lectures, but I think making more space for questions throughout the lecture rather than at the end of class would make it easier to digest.
He always saved time at the end for questions.
Not during lectures, but appeared to be pretty available at other times.
Certainly defined more clearly than other YSD courses.
Perhaps not consistently enforced, but clearly communicated
Never tried. Partially based on the instructors choice to not leave room for question or comment at the end of lectures.
Paul made it clear that he wanted students to meet with him outside of class if they needed it or wanted it. He was approachable and friendly.
Appeared so, but never really sought it out.
Its hard to imagine Paul in a not lecture capacity, but he knows so much, it might be worth it.
Most - I otherwise would have failed...?
I only missed one class due to a doctor's appointment
Few, I felt the class was not serving my needs or helping me understand more the different periods or plays assigned.
Changes in the culture of YSD would change the way this course is experienced.

Paul is very smart but the way he communicates the information is not clear for students that DO NOT speak English as their first language. 
He reads too much and explains very little. Often the class just feels very boring and you disengage.

Entirely depends on the TA leading the discussion. the first half of the semester with Nahuel was incredibly informative and useful. the second half with Ashley was not at all informative or useful. I felt in no way prepared for the final whereas Nahuel's sections left me feeling prepared for the midterm and the essay.
Interesting discussions.
Ashley was a really helpful and great discussion leader. She simplified topics and was always super prepared.
Often felt railroaded by the direction she wanted to go.
Entirely depends on the TA leading the discussion. Nahuel managed to pack in a lot of information into our hour together but Ashley seemed to only have 5-20 minutes of discussion materials.
Yes. It would be great if some more discussion happened during "lectures"
I believe so... I may have missed one due to illness but cannot remember.
Think I missed one. Also, if you're sick it was two absences on lecture/discussion day - again, wellness culture problem of YSD
Yes
No
I think i missed 1
all but 1
Yes
